articleBody.content-title-1: Find Tires & Auto Repair Recommendations for Your Ride
articleBody.content-text-1-1: Your car is made up of thousands of moving parts. Making sure all of these parts run smoothly mile after mile isn't easy, but you can bet we're up to the challenge. Firestone Complete Auto Care is here to service and repair your vehicle, from the engine to the exhaust system. We're also here to provide you with the information you need to make the best car care decisions for your specific vehicle. That's why we designed this simple tool: to help you determine what maintenance service or repair is right for your car, and when.
articleBody.content-text-2-1: Select your vehicle manufacturer to get started. We'll show you the correct tires, oil, battery, and brakes for your make and model, along with manufacturer-approved maintenance recommendations for oil changes, wheel alignment, fluid flushes, A/C service, and more.
articleBody.content-text-3-1: With this information in hand, you can give your car the excellent care it deserves. Help your car or truck hit the 200,000-mile marker—or beyond! And let other drivers wonder about what size tires to buy, when to get an oil change, and how often to get a brake fluid flush—with Firestone Complete Auto Care on your side, you'll already know.
articleBody.content-text-4-1: Since 1926, we've been committed to offering the right auto solutions and services to all of our customers. We have more than 1,700 locations and 4,000+ hardworking ASE-certified technicians nationwide, so you're never far from a reliable total car care experience. Check your recommended service schedule and turn to your nearest Firestone Complete Auto Care for the right service at the right time. Our Triple Promise Guarantee means that your car will be Fixed Right, Priced Right, and Done Right On Time, no matter how many miles the engine has under its serpentine belt! We're proud to keep your car running newer, longer.

isRelatedTo.name: Rear Axle Fluid
isRelatedTo.description: Change rear axle fluid every 100,000 miles (160,000 km). Rear axle fluid change may be waived if the axle was filled with 75W140 synthetic gear fluid meeting Ford specification WSL-M2C192-A, part number FITZ-19580-B or equivalent. Add four ounces (118 mL) of additive friction modifier XL-3 (EST-M2C118-A) or equivalent for complete refill of Traction-Lok rear axles. The axle fluid should be changed anytime the axle has been submerged in water.

articleBody.content-title-1: Your Guide to Ford F-150 Scheduled Maintenance
articleBody.content-text-1-1: Take care of your Ford F-150 and it'll take care of you. With the right maintenance at the right time, your F-150 has a good chance of hitting 200,000 miles or more.
articleBody.content-text-1-2: But how do you know what service to get and when? There's no need to guess when it's time to get F-150 maintenance, and no need to wait until something goes wrong.
articleBody.content-text-1-3: Just follow your 2013 Ford F-150 maintenance schedule! This recommended maintenance schedule is put together by Ford, your vehicle manufacturer.
articleBody.content-text-1-4: Scheduled maintenance services can vary depending on driving conditions, climate, and other factors; however, recommended maintenance usually includes services like oil changes, tire rotations, brake pad replacement, and fluid checks and flushes.
articleBody.content-text-1-5: Scheduling routine service appointments is one of the best ways to help extend your F-150's life, increase your vehicle safety, and prevent common 2013 Ford F-150 problems.
articleBody.content-title-2: Overview of Essential Ford F-150 Maintenance Needs
articleBody.content-text-2-1: Bring your 2013 Ford F-150 to Firestone Complete Auto Care for factory-recommended maintenance services and a skilled technician will start the appointment with a courtesy check.
articleBody.content-text-2-2: A courtesy check helps "set the stage" for your service and catch any small problems before they turn into big repairs.
articleBody.content-text-2-3: Each courtesy check includes a free battery test and an inspection of your F-150's windshield wiper blades, head and tail lights, filters, fluid levels, tires, and alignment.
articleBody.content-text-3-1: Maybe it's time to find a new auto battery for your 2013 Ford F-150. Batteries generally need to be replaced every three to five years.
articleBody.content-text-3-2: Yours may need to be replaced sooner depending on your driving habits and climate. Short trips and extreme temperatures can shorten the overall life expectancy of your Ford F-150 battery.
articleBody.content-text-3-3: While you could wait until your battery fails and you hear the dreaded "click," you're better off replacing it before then!
articleBody.content-text-3-4: Otherwise, you may find yourself (and your trusty F-150) stuck in the middle of nowhere.
articleBody.content-text-3-5: Your Ford F-150 won't be going anywhere without a strong battery.
articleBody.content-text-4-1: In addition to maintaining a strong battery, investing in regular oil changes can help your 2013 Ford F-150's engine run newer, longer.
articleBody.content-text-4-2: Ford recommends oil changes every 7,500 miles/6 months for 2008 and newer model-year Ford F-150s, and every 5,000 miles/6 months for 2007 and older model-year vehicles.
articleBody.content-text-4-3: Keep in mind that your oil change interval could be different given your driving style and climate.
articleBody.content-text-4-4: Talk to a Firestone Complete Auto Care technician to know when to change your oil. We'll also help you understand what type of oil to use for a 2013 Ford F-150.
articleBody.content-text-5-1: Maintaining your Ford F-150 steering and suspension system can improve ride comfort and help you maintain control of your vehicle. That's important if you plan on going where a tow truck can't, or hauling a heavy load!
articleBody.content-text-5-2: Trust our technicians to inspect all system components and if needed, provide Ford F-150 steering and suspension services including wheel alignment, strut replacement, power steering fluid changes, ball joint lubrication, and wheel bearing replacing.
articleBody.content-text-5-3: Components within your Ford F-150's steering system require regular maintenance.
articleBody.content-text-6-1: Without routine Ford F-150 maintenance, you (and your engine) could quickly lose your cool when there's a problem on the road–especially if that problem is an overheated engine or broken A/C.
articleBody.content-text-6-2: Our technicians have you covered there, too, with the tools and expertise to care for your entire Ford F-150 cooling, heating, and climate control system. Need a new Ford F-150 radiator? We got it. A/C smelling musty?
articleBody.content-text-6-3: We'll fix it. Firestone Complete Auto Care is the place to go for 2013 Ford F-150 maintenance!
articleBody.content-text-7-1: So visit us regularly, or visit us urgently.
articleBody.content-text-7-2: Many locations are open on weekends and in the evening.
articleBody.tips-title-1: Maintenance Tips for Your 2013 Ford F-150
articleBody.tips-text-1-1: Optional text. Helpful tips to follow.
articleBody.tip-text-1-3: If your 2013 F-150 is pulling to one side or the other, your tires or suspension system could be calling out for help.
articleBody.tip-text-2-1: Got 75,000 miles? Consider high mileage motor oil.
articleBody.tip-text-2-2: High mileage oil is formulated to address the specific problems encountered by high mileage vehicles, or those with more than 75,000 miles.
articleBody.tip-text-2-3: It can help reduce oil consumption, smoke, and emissions from older Ford F150 engines.
articleBody.tip-text-3-2: Bring your Ford F-150 in for a diagnostic code scan as soon as a dashboard warning light flashes on, whether it's your check engine or battery light.
articleBody.tip-text-3-3: Dashboard lights alert you to trouble under the hood.
articleBody.body-cta-title: Get Tires for Your Ford F-150
articleBody.body-cta-text: When it's time to buy new tires for your vehicle, turn to the skilled technicians at your local Firestone Complete Auto Care. Browse tires online and schedule an installation appointment today!

articleBody.content-text-1-2: If you're the type of driver who waits for something to go wrong with your vehicle, it might be time to change your ways, especially if you drive a 2013 Ford F-150.
articleBody.content-text-1-3: Routine engine tune-ups can bring power back to your truck.
articleBody.content-text-1-4: They're designed to help your engine start easier and run more efficiently, so you enjoy greater fuel economy and lower emissions.
articleBody.content-text-1-5: When you get routine engine tune-ups based on Ford's recommendations, you invest in your F-150's long-term health and engine performance.
articleBody.content-text-2-1: Your local Firestone Complete Auto Care offers a range of engine tune-up services for the 2013 Ford F-150.
articleBody.content-text-2-2: The first is the standard Firestone Tune-Up.
articleBody.content-text-2-3: It includes a complete visual inspection of engine components, installation of new spark plugs, and a lifetime warranty on parts*.
articleBody.content-text-2-4: The second service focuses on your F-150's filters, specifically replacing the air filter and fuel filter.
articleBody.content-text-2-5: The third tune-up option is a fuel system cleaning service, which is a three-step process that removes carbon deposits on your F-150's fuel injectors.
articleBody.content-text-2-6: The result? Restored fuel system performance.
articleBody.content-text-2-7: Keep in mind that your F-150's mileage and maintenance history can uniquely impact its tune-up needs.
articleBody.content-text-2-8: A one-size-fits-all engine tune-up procedure doesn’t necessarily exist.
articleBody.content-title-3: Where to Get a Ford F-150 Tune-Up
articleBody.content-text-3-1: Schedule your next 2013 F-150 engine tune-up service at Firestone Complete Auto Care.
articleBody.content-text-3-2: Follow Ford's recommended maintenance schedule or book an appointment as soon as you notice one of the following:
articleBody.content-text-3-3: decreased gas mileage, "rough" idling or stalling when stopped, engine knocking, or an illuminated check engine light.
articleBody.content-text-4-1: * Talk to a Firestone Complete Auto Care technician for full terms and conditions on warranties.
articleBody.tip-text-1-2: Spark plugs are small, but mighty.
articleBody.tip-text-1-3: The spark of electricity that the plug emits across a small gap creates the ignition for the combustion needed to start your car.
articleBody.tip-text-1-4: Without that spark, your car won't start.
articleBody.tip-text-2-2: Don't ignore puddles of fluid under your Ford F-150.
articleBody.tip-text-2-3: It could signal a coolant leak, brake fluid leak, or an oil leak.
articleBody.tip-text-2-4: Let any one of these leaks linger and it could cause irreversible engine damage.
articleBody.tip-text-3-2: They put extra wear and tear on engine components.
articleBody.tip-text-3-3: Smooth, gradual starts and stops, on the other hand, are a great way to help your engine run better.
articleBody.tip-text-3-4: They can also help maximize your fuel economy.
